headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2013
componenttext: Good afternoon, and good morning. Welcome to Lenovo's Q3 Result Webcast. This is Gary Ng, VP in Investor Relations at Lenovo. Before we start, let me introduce our management team with us today. We have our Chairman and CEO, Mr. Yang Yuanqing; and our CFO, Mr. Wong Wai Ming. We will start with our management presentations. After that, we'll take your questions. Now let me turn it over to Yuanqing.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2013
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. Happy new year to all of you. Lenovo had another record-setting quarter. I cannot wait to share our fantastic results with you. 
Last quarter, we achieved a record volume, record revenue and record profit. Let's start with our traditional PC business. Our PC sales volume grow almost 16 points ahead of the overall market. Our global market share reached another historical high, 15.9% with more than 14 million units shipped. Now, we have grown faster than the market for 15 straight quarters and have been the fastest-growing major PC company for 13 straight quarters. Our strong growth comes with record profitability. Our pretax income ratio reached 2.6%. That's 0.3% points better year-on-year, and our earnings increased by more than 33% year-on-year to reach USD 205 million. 
Record profits with record market share, this demonstrates that we have a very healthy business driving balance the growth worldwide. We did this by outgrowing the market in all customer and product segments, as well as geographies. 
EMEA, we outgrew the market by 36 points with strong performance across all parts of our business. We also steadily improved profitability in our consumer business while increasing its mix in overall revenue. In early 2009, we were #7 with less than 4% of the market share. But now, we reached the #2 in PCs with our record market share of more than 11%. It is even more impressive considering the challenging economic environment in the region. 
In our Asia Pacific, Latin American geo, we grew 13 points faster than the market. And then we improved profitability year-on-year. North America, outgrew the market by 18 points. In the U.S., we had a record share of 8.6% and continue to have a strong, profitable commercial business. 
In consumer, not only did we continue our strong growth, but we also saw initial success in the premier space. Our Yoga and the Twist now almost 30% of $700-and-above Windows 8 retail market. Even more impressively, we have 49% retail market share of Windows 8 device sales that were priced over USD $900. 
In China, our PC business remains strong even in our slower market, and we protected our profit pool perfectly to fuel our growth in other areas. We once again increased our market share and further improved our already healthy profitability by another 0.3% points year-on-year. Clearly, our PC business is healthy and will continue to get stronger. More importantly, beyond the PC, we have built a strong foundation for our PC Plus businesses, which is growing even faster. Our PC Plus growth starts with our strong performance in phones. Total phone sales grew more than 50% year-on-year to reach 9.4 million units of which, smartphone growth was even more impressive. In China, our smartphone business actually doubled year-on-year. 
Outside of China, we had a strong early response in Russia, India, Indonesia and other new markets. Globally, we sold over 9 million smartphones last quarter. Best of all, for the first time, we were profitable in smartphone sales globally. This is another milestone. At the same time, our worldwide tablet business not only grow almost 80% year-on-year to reach almost the 800,000 units, but also was profitable. Overall, our Mobile Internet Digital Home businesses now accounts for 11% of Lenovo's overall revenue. While we are still focusing on growing our MIDH business worldwide, we are now driving profitable growth in China. 
Today, according to IDC, in overall smart connectivity devices including PC, smartphone and tablet, Lenovo ranks #3 worldwide behind only Apple and Samsung. But definitely, we are not satisfied, and we'll continue our march to the top. 
Our strong growth, record profitability and rapid expansion as a PC+ company, all have been guided by our Protect and Attack strategy. There are 4 critical elements to our success in all these areas. The right strategy, efficient business model, Innovative products and our diverse team and the global culture. Combined with our world-class execution, we have delivered excellent results in various market conditions. In fact, we've reached the important milestone this quarter. Our Attack business now accounts for 50% of our total revenue. Now, our strategy, we have continued to guide us as we reorganized to aim for even stronger future growth. 
Given our record performance, you may ask why we are reorganizing now. When we established our current structure, we were much smaller and had only one business outside of China, which was our commercial PC business. Today, we are much more diverse business. In addition to commercial PCs, we have a strong global consumer business and have a fast-growing MIDH business as well as servers and storage. These businesses require different business models. The transactional business is more about speed and efficiency while relationship focuses more on quality and the customerization. So we are creating 2 end-to-end business groups to enhance each business model, Lenovo Business Group and the Think Business Group. The new structure will significantly improve our product development cycle, time-to-market, marketing campaign as well as day-to-day operations. 
Also, we want to expand our presence in the premier space. Our legendary single brand already has a strong position in commercial, and we believe we can extend to that into consumer as well. So the new end-to-end organization, we want to further leverage our innovation excellence to lead in both commercial and the consumer premium space. Our innovative products have long been a critical part of our success. Innovation enabled us to break through in the premier market in North America, a market we were never able to enter in the past. 
With our best-selling Yoga and the Twist, we did not reach this point by accident. We have dedicated years of hard work to innovation. At CES in 2010, we broke new ground with the IdeaPad U1, the early idea of our convertible PC. Last year, with the successful launch of Yoga, we formally showcased our fully developed concept of convertibles. Our best-selling products now are the outcome of continuous enhancement through the years. In the last couple of years, we build our own smartphone and tablet businesses from scratch. In fact, the groundwork of our Mobile Internet research and technology began 6 to 7 years ago. We have not reached here by following others' footsteps. And at this year's Consumer Electronic Show, our award-winning Horizon table PC is the latest convincing examples. We created a new product category and even more, it helped build the image of Lenovo as the global innovation leader. Also at CES, with our other newest products like the K900 smartphone and the Helix convertible PC, we owned a record 15 major awards, by far the biggest winner at the CES. It is more evident than ever that the Lenovo's innovative image is more and more recognized globally. Innovation is in our DNA, and we will continue to drive our growth in PCs and the PC Plus products. 
Looking ahead, we are committed to the PC industry and definitely are in a stronger position than other competitors. While we are on course to become the worldwide PC leader, we will continue to focus on improving profitability. 
Last quarter, I committed that our goal is to improve our PTI margin by 1 point over 3 years. And now, I still stand firm to that commitment. At the same time, we will continue to focus and to grow faster in all smart connected devices. We believe this will yield healthy returns for our investors in the long term. 
Thank you, everybody. I'd now turn to our CFO, Wai Ming. Wai Ming, please.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2013
componenttext:
Thank you, Yuanqing. Hello, everyone. This is Wai Ming. I will take you through Lenovo's financial and operational performance in quarter 3. Next chart, please. 
We continue to grow in both sales and profit with margin expansion even when the global PC market declined in quarter 3. We have delivered 13 consecutive quarters of year-on-year growth. Our balanced performance has been driven by our successful execution of our Protect and Attack strategy. I think the strong performance of our Mobile Internet business is a significant strength that we believe will help us drive sustainable growth even in challenging market conditions. 
Our PC shipments in quarter 3 were up 8%, and PC sales were up 7% year-on-year to $8 billion. Our strong performance in Mobile Internet business, especially smartphone, have continued more to the group's strong revenue growth. Sales in our Mobile Internet business were up 77%, year-on-year to $998 million. Sales of other goods and services were $393 million. 
Group sales grew 12% year-on-year to approximately, $9.4 billion. Gross profit was about $1.1 billion, up 15% year-on-year. Gross profit margin improved by 0.4 points to 11.8% year-on-year primarily due to scaling benefits, but dipped slightly from 12.1% in quarter 2 mostly due to increased mix of the consumer business. 
Operating expenses including our continued investment in R&D and branding increased 13% year-on-year to $838  million to support our growth. Our E-to-R ratio was relatively stable year-on-year at 9.2%, but down from 9.7% in last quarter due to our continuing efforts in efficiency improvement. 
Operating profit was $243 million, up 26% year-on-year. Pretax income was $246 million, up 28% year-on-year. This is a record high level for the group. PTI margin was 2.6%, up year-on-year and quarter-on-quarter. Effective tax rate for quarter 3 was slightly below 20%, as a result all better margin. Profit attributable to equity holders is $205 million, up 34% year-on-year. Net margin was 2.2%, an improvement of over 15% quarter-on-quarter and 20% year-on-year. Basic EPS improved to USD 0.0199 representing a 33% increase from USD 0.015 last year. 
Next chart, please. Our balance sheet in quarter 3 remains strong. Noncurrent assets were about $4.3 billion, slightly higher compared to the level at 30 of September 2012. Changes in current assets and current liabilities were largely due to increased activities during the quarter. Increase in the inventory level is due to the preparation for the Chinese New Year holiday sales, expansion into emerging markets, as well as increasing component inventory due to pricing benefit and more in-house inventory. 
We had net current assets of around $349 million at the end of December. The noncurrent liability were around $2.1 billion. 
Now, let's go through the cash and working capital in the next chart. Our cash flow continued to be healthy in quarter 3. As a result, our bank deposit and cash level was higher compared to last year and last quarter. Our net cash reserve was strong at $4.2 billion compared to last year and last quarter. We continue to do well in managing our working capital. Inventory days were 20, up 3 days again last year and 1 day compared to last quarter. Receivable days were 36, up 2 days and 3 days compared to last year and last quarter as well. Both increases are driven by our expansion in consumer business. 
Payable days were 61 days in quarter 3, flat quarter-on-quarter. The decline of 7 days compared to last year was, again, due to our expansion in the consumer business. We expect it to be -- remain stable. As a result, the cash conversion cycle in quarter 3 was a negative 5 days, again, negative 17 days last year and negative 9 days last quarter. The change was driven by our strategic business decision in the emerging markets and consumer business, including MIDH, together with our hybrid strategy of increasing our mix of in-house manufacturing to enhance end-to-end efficiency and product time-to-market. Nevertheless, the group cash position remains at a very strong level to drive future growth. 
Next chart, please. The group has record high shipments and market share in quarter 3, even as the China PC market slow down, and we also see strong performance across the board relative to the markets. We continued to perform well in China in both PC and Mobile Internet business. Despite the negative growth in China PC market, we recorded a 17% growth revenue year-on-year to about $4.1 billion in China. Our PC sales increased around 6% year-on-year to about $3.2 billion driven by our strong growth in emerging cities and the goal organization. We achieved record higher market share in quarter 3, and our market share is even bigger than the total of the next 4 players. 
China PC operating profit increased to $200 million, also a record high level for us, while our margin further improved to 6.3% year-on-year. 
Our Mobile Internet business in China continued to show strong growth and provided a strong support for our continuing high growth in China in quarter 3. Sales increased by 83% to $895 million, which accounts for 22% of the China total sales revenue in quarter 3. MIDH profitability also saw continuous improvement in quarter 3 particular, with the help of our strong China's smartphone business, which turned profitable for the first time in this quarter. We will continue to invest in the PC+ area to drive our future growth. 
APLA. Sales were down 1.6% year-on-year at about $1.7 billion in APLA despite our shipment growth against the declining PC market in the region. Operating profit improved slightly against the loss recorded last year, but it dropped quarter-to-quarter. Latin America and Brazil where the markets account for the majority of the loss in this quarter. We expect our new manufacturing hub and the acquisition of CCE in Brazil that we closed at the beginning of this January will help accelerate our expansion in the country and therefore, contribute to the further development of the region's profitability over time.
EMEA. We had a very encouraging quarter in EMEA as sales grew 17% year-on-year to about $2.3 billion. Strong growth in emerging markets in the region like Eastern and Southern Europe, Middle East and Africa, as well as consumer business, contributed to the strong growth in the region. In Quarter 3, we maintained #1 positions in Russia and Germany. We achieved record high market share in Western Europe at 11.3% and became the #2 PC player for the first time. 
Operating margin remained stable both year-on-year and quarter-on-quarter at 2%. Our Attack in the consumer business in the region continued to gain traction that resulted in share gain. Our consumers in EMEA continued to be profitable with improved margin in quarter 3 from better scaling. We will continue to attack in the consumer business and expect it to provide additional support to our margin improvement over time.
North America. We continued to achieve strong growth premium against the market decline in the region with record share in the U.S. in North America. Sales grew 8% year-on-year to about $1.3 billion. We had a successful drive in our consumer business especially with the high-end Window 8 products like Yoga, leveraging the Christmas holiday season to build a solid foundation for future growth. This is a first time that are premium-priced consumer product has broken into the main retail chain in the U.S.. The increased mix of our consumer business at the of [indiscernible] of scale led to a decline in the operating profit from $38 million last year to $34 million this year. 
Next chart, please. We have a more balanced product portfolio helped by our expansion in consumer PC and Mobile Internet business. Notebook unit shipments and sales were up 9% and 8% year-on-year respectively. Unit shipments and sales in our desktop business were up 6% and 1% year-on-year, respectively. 
Our MIDH business continued to show strong performance, up 77% year-on-year in sales, led by the smartphone business, which fueled the strong growth of our group. Our smartphone business has become profitable, and we have also started to expand into 7 countries in emerging markets. 
Our tablet business also showed strong growth in quarter 3. We will continue to invest in innovation and broaden our product portfolio to enhance our competitiveness and service to our customers. 
Next chart, please. I want to take this opportunity to report the stages of our recent corporate transactions. In this chart, we have included highlights of the deals and their progress for your reference and how they fit into our existing strategy. The integration of all of these transactions is well on track. We expect this transactions will help provide a steady contribution to the company alongside our organic engines. 
Before I end my presentation, I want to give you some color on the market outlook. Despite uncertainties in the global economy impacting the PC market growth in short term, we remain confident that we can continue to outperform the worldwide PC market and to improve our operating margin. While our core PC business is performing well, our Mobile Internet business, especially our smartphone business in China, has also started contributing to the group work in sales and improving profitability. We have also began to invest our smartphone businesses in 7 countries in emerging markets. This balanced performance is a significant strength that will help us drive sustainable growth even in challenging market conditions. We will stay focused in our efficiency improvement initiatives and growth opportunities. We'll continue to invest in core competence building and product innovation to drive sustainable future growth. 
These investment, however, will cause the expense-to-revenue ratio to increase in the short term especially during quarter 4, which is a typical low season for us, and the ratio will be higher, sequentially, compared to quarter 3. We have a healthy balance sheet, and we will continue to look for M&A opportunities in areas that can help us to accelerate our growth.
Now thank you very much. We will take your question now.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q4 2013 Earnings Call, May 23, 2013
componenttext:
Thank you. So good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. Even in a challenging economic and market environment, Lenovo had a strong fourth quarter to close another record of fiscal year. 
I'm excited to share our fantastic results with you and to discuss our strategy for the year ahead. 
Now let me start with our fourth quarter. We have now been the fastest-growing major PC company for 14 straight quarters. We delivered a strong performance in a difficult market. Lenovo was only the PC company to increase the volume year-on-year. We've reached our PC market share of over 15% -- 15.5%, gaining more than 2 points year-on-year. On the PC Plus side, our smartphone business in China, more than doubled in volume year-on-year, and we were profitable for the second straight quarter. We also rolled out the smartphones in over 6 markets and increased the tablet sales worldwide by 23% year-on-year. We also delivered a strong profitability. Our pretax income ratio grew almost 1 point year-on-year to more than 2% up, and our earnings increased 9% to 10% year-on-year to reach $127 million. 
Our fourth quarter was a strong finish to another record-setting year for Lenovo. For whole fiscal year, Lenovo outgrew the market by 18 points to reach our record PC volume of over 52 million units and our record PC market share of nearly 16%, up 2.6 points year-on-year. 
Our revenue reached an all-time high at almost USD 34 billion, up 15% year-on-year. More importantly, at the same time, we achieved a record profit with a record earnings of USD 675 million, up 34% year-on-year. Two quarters ago, I was committed to you to improve our profitability. We actually delivered that -- delivered it. What I'm most proud of is these record results came from balanced growth across all geographies, as well as product and the customer segments. 
In EMEA, despite a very challenging economic environment, we outgrew the PC market by more than 36 points, and gained 3 points this year year-on-year, and reached the double digit market share for the year for the first time. We jumped from #5 to #2 player in just 1 year. While growing rapidly, we still improve the segment operating profit for USD 147 million, up 77% year-on-year. This was thanks largely to our strong profit improvement in the consumer space. 
In Asia Pacific and Latin America, we outgrew the market by over 20 points, gaining more than 2 points of the share to over 11% for the year. At the same time, this geo started to contribute the profit to our company. 
In North America, we outgrew the market by 20 points to reach our all-time high, almost 9% market share for the fiscal year, while the segment operating profit improved for USD 168 million. We also had the record market share in the United States of 8.5%. 
And in China, we face the more challenged last fiscal year, but we still increased our market share by 2.6 points to nearly 35% for the fiscal year. 
We also increased our PC margin by near -- nearly 0.5 point to more than 6%. We did well despite a weaker market, which we believe is a short-term issue tied to transition, changes to rural subsidiaries policy, real estate price control and other short-term measures. But we still low penetration rates of the PC and smartphone and the continuing urbanization, that market will grow in the long term and provide more growth opportunity for Lenovo. 
Our PC business definitely delivered a record year. While we expect to continue this strong performance in PCs, we are now focused on becoming a true major player in PC Plus. 
In smartphones, we strengthened our #2 position in China, with volume up over 368% year-on-year. At the same time, we have now entered the phase of profitable growth. Worldwide, we have a strong early results in all 5 new markets.
In tablets, our worldwide sales were up 74% year-on-year, establishing a strong foundation for even faster growth in the coming year. Overall, while we where #3 in worldwide Smart Connected Devices, which includes PC, tablet and smartphone. And for the year, our mobile business contributed a 9% of Lenovo's overall revenue, almost double that of last year. We are confident that we will deliver even more PC Plus growth in the year ahead. Our record profitability and the PC market share, as well as our rapid expansion as a PC Plus company, have been guided by our Protect and Attack strategy. Our future success will continue to be based on 4 critical elements, the right strategy and the good execution. Efficient business model, innovative product and our diversity and global culture. Now I want to discuss our updated strategy and how we will drive even stronger future growth and the PC Plus era.
In PCs, while we will continue our Protect and Attack strategy, protect China and the global enterprise business and attack emerging market consumer and SMB, we will be more focused on improving profitability. 
Overall, we have a strong PC business foundation that we are confident we'll be even stronger and more profitable in the year ahead, which we will help us deliver our commitment of improving profitability. But at the same time, we are now much more than just a PC company, and our PC Plus business will grow even faster next year. 
In smartphones, we first want to become the market leader in China. In addition, we will grow very aggressively in emerging markets by leveraging our rich product portfolio, strong brand and broader channel networks. This strategy led to our successful launch in Russia, India in Indonesia and other markets. And we will definitely expand to even more countries this year. At the same time, we will focus more heavily on our tablet business to grow even faster. We will attack this opportunity by leveraging our deeper understanding of both Android and Windows to deliver a differentiated product portfolio that satisfies both consumers and the business users. Our target is within 2 years to achieve the same level of the market share that we have in notebooks today. 
In addition, we will grow our server and the storage business to become a relevant global player in the next 3 years. 
So this will be our strategic direction. Side-by-side with our strategy, we will continue to strengthen our business model. First, our reasonably organization will drive better execution of our strategy. As I said the last quarter, we have reorganized our structure and established the 2 end-to-end business groups and Lenovo business group. The new structure will significantly improve our product development cycle, time to market, as well as day-to-day operations. 
Second, we continue to strengthen our vertical integration. While collaborating closely with our partners, we will further enhance our in-house manufacturing capabilities. In the last year, we have begun production of the new facilities in China, in Brazil and in United States. Looking ahead, our end-to-end model will give us a unique competitive advantage in the PC Plus area. Last but not least, we will continue to improve efficiency across our company. Every function will continue to focus on driving efficiency, reducing expenses and shifting investment to growing and strategically important areas. With a strong business model, innovation excellence is even more critical to succeeding feeding into PC Plus area. In the future, you will see us differentiate our products based on our core technology breakthroughs. You will see us integrate hardware, software and services perfectly for the best possible user experience. Our goal is to leverage our innovation advantage to win through differentiation. With the right strategy, efficient business model and innovative products, our diverse team and unified global culture is the foundation for everything we do. And this diversity and unity will continue to be our competitive advantage. 
Looking ahead, it's clear that our industry has changed. We are now in the PC Plus era. At Lenovo, we have built the foundation and are well-positioned to continue our strong momentum. We are ready to start another journey into PC Plus era to continue outpacing the market just like we have done with the PCs in the past 4 years. So thank you, everyone. Now let me turn to our CFO, Wai Ming. Thank you.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q4 2013 Earnings Call, May 23, 2013
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Thank you, Yuanqing. I will take you through Lenovo financials and operational performance for our quarter 4 and for the full fiscal year 2013. 
And next chart, please. Yuanqing has just shared with you our fiscal year 2013 performance, which is a year of success for Lenovo. Quarter 4 obviously is another good quarter for us. We continue to grow in both sales and profit with margin expansion even with the global PC market decline in quarter 4. This is in fact the 14th consecutive quarters that we achieved this year-on-year growth despite the PC market has showed a growth for the last 4 quarters. Our balanced performance has been driven by the successful execution of our Protect and Attack strategy that enable us to continue to grow our top line without losing or giving up probability. 
Against a very challenging market environment, our mobile Internet business is a very significant strength that had helped us to drive the sustainable growth. Group sales grew 4% year-to-year to around $7.8 billion. Our PC shipment was flat year-on-year against a global PC market decline of around 13% year-on-year. Lenovo is the only PC company that maintain shipment volume year-on-year among the top 5 players in quarter 4 according to IDC. PC sales were up 3% year-on-year to around $6.9 billion. Our strong performance in mobile Internet business, especially to smartphone in China, helps contribute more to the growth revenue growth. Sales in our mobile Internet business were up 74% year-on-year to $736 million. Sales of other good and services were $147 million. Gross profit was about $963 million, up 20% year-to-year. Gross profit margin improved by 1.5 points to 2.3% year-on-year, primarily due to the lower base last year caused by the shortage of the hard disk drive. It was also 0.5% quarter-to-quarter, mainly due to improving MIDH margin and the scaling benefit. Operating expenses, including our continued investment in the research and development and some cost incurred in the integration of our recent acquisition, increased 13% year-on-year to $794 million to support our growth. 
Our EER ratio was up year-on-year to 10.1% against 9.4% last year and 9.2% last quarter. Operating profit $169 million, up 67% year-to-year. Pretax income, $166 million, up 63% year-on-year. PTI margin was 2.1% against 1.4% last year. And effective rate for quarter 4 was around 25% as a result of our better margin. Profit attributable to equity holders is $127 million, up 90% year-on-year. And net margin was 1.6% against 0.9% last year. 
For the full year, we finished the year with record high revenue. Revenue was up 13% to $33.9 billion. Gross profit up 18% to approximately $4.1 million and gross margin expanded to 12% from 11.7% last year. The E/R was flat and 9.7%. We have a record high net pretax income of $801 million, up 38% compared to last year over attributable to equity holders for the full year is also a record high of $635 million, up 34% year-on-year. 
Basic EPS, USD 0.122 in quarter 4 and $0.616 for the full year. The board decided this morning in the meeting to declare a final dividend HKD of 0.14 per share. 
Next chart, please. Our balance sheet has remained strong. Noncurrent assets was $4.5 million. The increase from that of 31st March 2012 was due to the consolidation of our recent acquisitions, the new joint venture plant and investment in the IT system. Increasing the inventory was largely due to the increase in our in-house manufacturing, consolidation of recent acquisitions by CCE in quarter 4, increased mix of our consumer product and also increase on our sales. Other changes in current assets and current liabilities were largely due to our increased level of activities. Overall, the balance sheet remains healthy despite quarter 4 typically being a low season for us. We have net current assets of around $299 million as of 31st March 2013. The noncurrent liability was around $2.1 million. 
Next chart, please? Bank deposit and cash level were lower compared to last year due to our capital expenditure and settlement to complete our recent acquisitions. Changing our cash conversion cycle has also impacted the cash flow in quarter 4, as we increase the mix of our consumer in mobile Internet, device business and in-house manufacturing and started integrating our recent acquisitions. We drew down an outstanding bank facility at the end of quarter 2 before that resulted in higher bank borrowings compared to the last year. The net cash reserve dropped to around $3.1 billion. 
We continue to do well in managing our working capital inventory days 26 come up 8 days again last year, due to the expansion into the consumer business and emerging market ramped up our new in-house manufacturing and integration of our recent acquisitions. Receivable days were 40 days, up 5 days compared to last year, driven by our expansion in consumer business and mobile Internet devices, as far as the integration of our recent acquisitions. Payable days, 73 days, up 3 days compared to last year, as result of cash conversions cycle in quarter 4 was negative 7 days against the negative 17 days last year. 
For the full year, our cash conversion cycle change from negative 19 days to negative 8 days. The change was driven by strategic business mix expansion into emerging market and our consumer business, including MIDH, together with a hybrid strategy of increasing our mix of in-house manufacturing to enhance our end-to-end efficiency, as well as product time-to-market. Nevertheless, the group's cash position remain very strong level. We still have a very strong level of cash to drive our future growth. 
Next chart, please. Now looking at the geography, we continue to do well in all geographies in quarter 4 for both our PC and our mobile Internet business, and our PC Plus strategy resulting in a margin improvement in all regions year-on-year. Despite the decline in the global PC market in quarter 4, the group continued to show shipment growth in most of that geos and share gains in all geos, with record high market share in APLA, EMEA and North America, while our mobile Internet device business, especially our business in -- especially our smart business in China, continue to show strong growth momentum. 
China. Total revenue from China was 8% year-on-year, driven by strong growth by our mobile Internet device, which grew 74% year-on-year. Our smartphone business in China continue to be profitable in quarter 4 for the second consecutive quarter. Revenue from our PC business was down 2% year-on-year. However, owing to -- due to the decline in the overall PC market in China but we manage to hold up and further improve our PC operating margin. It was up year-on-year and quarter-to-quarter to 6.4% as we focus on upholding margin in the declining market. As a result, overall margin in China was up 1.5 point year-on-year and 0.02 points quarter-to-quarter to 4.9%. We remain confident that our PC Plus strategy is fully operational in China and can continue to drive growth in sales, as well as profit in China. 
For APLA, revenues down 7% year-on-year to about $1.7 billion in APLA despite shipment growth against a declining PC market in the region. Operating profit improved slightly compared to last year, breakeven level, even though under the yen -- even though with the yen begin depreciation impact. Latin America and Brazil remained a key market showing loss this quarter. We have included the CCE figures for the first time in this quarter. We expect that it will help to accelerate our expansion in Brazil, and therefore will contribute to the further improvement in the region's profitability over time. 
For EMEA, we had a very encouraging quarter in EMEA, with record high market share and revenue grew 6% year-to-year to about $1.8 billion. Strong growth in emerging markets and consumer business contributed to the strong growth in the region. In quarter 4, we achieved record high market share in Western Europe and became the #2 PC player for the second consecutive quarter. Operating margin continued to improve year-on-year and quarter-to-quarter to 2.3%. Our consumer in this region was profitable in quarter 4 and achieved profitable for the full year for the first time. We have the right innovative product, the right organizational structure and strong leadership, and we have built a much more effective business model in the consumer -- for our consumer business in the region, and we are very confident to outperform the market or to continue to outperform the market and that will support the margin improvement over time. 
For North America, we continue to achieve a very strong growth premium against the market decline in the region and record share in U.S. in North America. Revenue for North America was up 13% year-on-year to about $1.2 billion. Continue to outperform well in the commercial business, while building foundation of our consumer business to drive future growth in the region. Operating margin improved year-on-year and quarter-to-quarter to 3.6%. We're optimistic about our strategy, execution and outlook in the region which should continue to drive a stable operating margin. 
Next chart, please. We have a more balanced product portfolio, however, in expansion in the consumer PC and mobile Internet device business. Notebook unit shipments were flat with 15 point premium for market. The sales were down 2% year-on-year, respectively. Unit shipments in sales in our desktop were flat again with a 12 point premium, sales down 2% year-on-year. Our MIDH business continue to show strong performance, 74% growth year-on-year in sales, led by our smartphone business in China with obviously fuel growth for the entire group. 
Next chart, please. I want at this opportunity to report the status of our recent corporate transactions. In this chart, we have included the highlights of the deals and their progress for your reference and how this fit into our existing strategy. The integration of all these transactions is well on track. We expect this transaction will provide us a steady contribution to the company, alongside with our organic engines. 
Before I end my presentation to my want to give you some color on the market outlook. Our PC Plus strategy has been working well to drive the good growth in sales and profit, with margin expense and in the past several quarters and years. Strong growth momentum in our business -- in our mobile Internet device business, especially our smartphone business in China, has helped to fuel the group's solid growth with the improving profitability we expect this trend to continue. We will continue to roll out our smartphone business in emerging markets and our tablet business in mature market. Our core PC business is performing well despite the uncertainties in the global economy impacting the PC market growth in the short term. We remain very confident that we can continue to outperform the global PC market and to improve our operating margin. We have been successful in upholding our share and profits in the Protect strategy in China and enterprise business, while at the same time our investment in our Attack strategy in the past several years have already enable us to reach critical mass with most emerging market in our consumer business, which I've already shown profitability. We expect this investment to start generating returns to the group even in a very challenging market environment. We will stay focused on our efficiency improvement initiative in growth opportunities. We'll continue to invest in our core competence building and product innovation and redeploy resources to invest in the high-growth area and to drive sustainable future growth. We have a very a high healthy balance sheet, which provides us the flexibility for executing our M&A strategy in order to capture the opportunities in the high-growth area, which obviously would help to accelerate our future growth. Now thank you very much and we would take your questions.

componenttext: Good morning and good evening. Welcome to Lenovo's Q1 result webcast. This is Gary Ng, VP Investor Relations at Lenovo. headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Aug 14, 2013
componenttext:
Hello, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Last quarter, Lenovo once again delivered very strong results. Although the global PC market continued to decline, last quarter it shrank 11% year-on-year, Lenovo still delivered strong results. Our market share was up almost 2 points year-on-year to reach our record share of 16.7%. Now we are the clear #1 PC company in the world for the first time. This is an important milestone and our balanced business is the main driver to achieve this dream. Last quarter, China PC market declined by 14% year-on-year. 
Although Lenovo's business is still very healthy and even improved the profit margin by almost 1 point, the fact is that, in the past, if the China market lags behind the global market, it would inactively impact our overall growth significantly. But today, our Europe and Americas businesses have become another pillar to our company. They outgrew the market significantly, and ensured our PC business revenue growth is still positive and our overall business is still strong. 
Here, we must thank the successful strategy and the execution over the past few years. Our successful attack battle for emerging and the consumer business has given us the momentum. We can see, not only rapid growth in emerging markets, like Eastern Europe, Middle East/Africa, Brazil and Asia. But also, our consumer businesses in North America and in Western Europe have turned into growth engines for our overall business. 
Today, we not only have our more balanced business across geographies but also, achieved a greater balance between commercial and the consumer segments. In fact, we used the 4 to 5 years to build our previously China-only consumer business into now the world's largest consumer business. Of course, other than ensuring a healthy PC business under such a tough environment, we have long realized the industry would go through major changes, and it is at a turning point right now. Fortunately, Lenovo has been preparing for this change for a couple of years and now, our efforts are starting to pay off. 
In smartphones, we grew our volumes significantly. Last quarter, our worldwide volume grew by 130% year-on-year and we are now #4 player in worldwide smartphone share according to the latest IDC report. In China, the world's largest smartphone market, we sold more than 11 million units and continued to strengthen our #2 position and because of that, our China business, overall, still grew by 6%, even with PC market in significant decline. 
In markets outside of China, we also met good progress, like in our first wave of Indonesia, India, Russia and Vietnam. Most recently, we expanded into even more markets like Brazil, Thailand and Malaysia, and have received good initial results as well. 
In tablets, our 4 geos all revved up their motors and then they drove our sales volume to more than triple year-on-year. Last quarter, our combined sales of smartphones and the tablets surpassed the PCs' for the first time. Our revenue from mobile internet businesses now account for 14% of our overall business and once again, we had our record share in global smart-connected devices with over 7%, which includes smartphones, tablets and PCs. Now we are transforming from a PC company to a PC Plus company in full speed. We are confident that we will achieve even greater success in the future. Our confidence still comes from the same success factors that we always talk about: right strategy, efficient business model, innovating products and a diverse team and a global culture. 
Today, I want to emphasize on innovation and the business model. The first is innovation. We will center on user experience by blending hardware, software and applications for greater end-to-end experience and we will win more customers with products that are more stylish, more exciting, and more user-friendly. 
 
In fact, Lenovo will launch a series of cool products for this holiday season. We will unveil the next generation of our multimode products, including the new Yoga and the uniquely designed tablets. Our new wave of smartphones will be even thinner, lighter with more and better features, particularly around the security, collaboration and cloud. 
Okay, I'd better stop here and come back to the rest for my earnings announcement. 
The reason the industry trends also gave us confidence is they clearly favor our business model. The industry is entering a phase of transformation. According to IDC data, the premier smartphone and tablet markets have slowed, while the mainstream and entry-level markets continued to see rapid growth. At the same time, the market growth is also shifting from mature markets to emerging markets. Even within mature markets, customers are switching phones much more quickly than before. In fact, in the U.S., some carriers are starting to change their policy to allow customers to switch their phones every 12 months or even just 6 months instead of 2 to 3 years. So this customer behavior change gives companies that can offer fashionable, affordable products and develop products quickly, more growth opportunity. Lenovo is this kind of company. 
We have a rich product portfolio that covers all price bands, thanks to our speedy product development cycle and frequent product upgrades. We have a very efficient end-to-end business model with disciplined operation. Our in-house manufacturing can quickly turn our innovations into high-quality, cost-efficient products for customers in both mature markets and the emerging markets. 
At the same time, even though we are consistently improving our profitability, we set reasonable margin targets. This means we are able to provide customers, especially mainstream customers, truly affordable products. 
In 1996, a PC with a Pentium chip was a premier product in China. With our highly efficient business model, Lenovo launched a campaign to offer it at less than RMB 10,000. That premier product overnight became affordable to mainstream customers. It was the time when the PC market in China transformed from premier to mainstream. And the Lenovo grasped that critical opportunity and built a solid foundation for our success in PCs. 
Smartphones and the tablets are going through a similar transformation. With our core competence and the success for experience in PCs, we are confident that we can replicate that success in the PC Plus area. 
Thank you. Now, let me turn it to our CFO, Wai Ming.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Aug 14, 2013
componenttext:
Thank you, Yuanqing. I will take you through Lenovo's financial and operational performance in quarter 1. Next chart, please. 
We continue to grow in both sales and profit with margin expansion even when the global PC market declined in quarter 1. This is the 15th consecutive quarters that we achieved this year-on-year growth, despite the worldwide PC market showing negative growth for the last 5 quarters. 
Our performance has been driven by the solid execution of our Protect and Attack strategy that enables us to continue our growth in top line without giving us profitability. Over the last few quarters, which we witnessed a challenging PC market environment, strong growth in our mobile internet business has continued to help us drive sustainable growth for the group. 
Group sales grew 10% year-on-year to around $8.8 billion. Sales in our mobile internet business were up 105% year-on-year to $1.2 billion. Strong performance in mobile internet business, especially smartphone, helped drive the group's top line growth. PC and related sales were up 2% year-on-year to around $7.3 billion. Sales of other goods and services were at $277 million. 
We reported in the last quarter that we have changed the way we organize our back-end operations by setting up 2 business group units, namely the Think business group and Lenovo business group. This helps enhance our end-to-end operating efficiency and innovation. This also resulted in some changes in cost classification. As a result, effective from this fiscal year, certain item used to be in the cost of goods sold, such as global supply chain and surface overheads, have now been reclassified into operating expense. There is no impact to operating profit, although both gross profit and expense will increase by around $65 million in quarter 1. 
Gross profit was about $1.2 billion, up 14% year-on-year. Gross profit margin was 13.6%, improved by 0.5 points year-on-year on a like-for-like comparison. The year-on-year improvement is largely due to modern improvement in PC from better average selling prices and probability improvement from our mobile internet business. 
Operating expense increased by 14% to $989 million. The operating expense in quarter 1 has included expense incurred in the CCE and EMC joint venture that we have just started the integration in the last quarter 4. Meanwhile, as part of our Protect and Attack strategy, we have taken resource actions to further improve our profitability in our PC business and continued to deploy resource in our PC Plus strategy, in order to drive further growth in revenue and profitability. This resulted in a $17 million severance expenses incurred in quarter 1. Our E/R ratio was up year-on-year to 11.3% against 10.8% last year. But if we exclude the severance expenses, the E/R ratio would be lower. 
Operating profit in quarter 1 was $202 million, up 11% year-on-year. We recorded a net nonoperating income of $13 million, mainly from incentives received for our investment in Wuhan mobile internet and manufacturing hub. Pretax income was $215 million, up 16% year-on-year. 
I want to highlight that netting of both nonoperating income and severance expenses, expansion in both our operating and PTI margin have been on track to close to 2.5%. The effective tax rate for quarter 1 was 21%, in line with our average run rate around 20% to 25%. Profit attributable to equity holders is $174 million, up 23% year-on-year. Net margin in quarter 1 was 2% against 1.8% last year. 
Now let's take a look at the balance sheet in the next chart. Our balance sheet in quarter 1 remains strong. Noncurrent assets were about $4.65 billion, slightly higher than the level at 31st March 2013. Increase in the inventory was largely due to increase in parts and components inventory needed for our increasing in-house manufacturing in China and Brazil. Consolidation of recent acquisitions like CCE, as well as finished goods, especially mobile internet device, to prepare for the summer sales season in quarter 2. 
In summary, our inventory level is at a healthy level, taking into consideration of our business growth. Other changes in current assets and current liabilities were due largely to increased activities during the quarter. We had net current assets of around $331 million at the end of June. The noncurrent liabilities were at around $2.2 billion. 
Let's go through the cash and working capital in the next chart. We have continued to leverage our strong cash resource to support our growth in driving strategic expansion in high-growth areas, such as consumer business, emerging markets and mobile internet device business. But as a result, the cash conversion cycle has come down to negative 1 day in Q1, again negative 13 days last year and negative 7 days in last quarter 4. Our bank deposit and cash level remained strong in Q1. It was lower compared to last year due to our capital expenditure and settlement to complete our recent acquisitions, as well as changing our cash conversion cycle. We drew down an outstanding bank facility in last Q2 before it lapsed, that resulted at -- in a higher bank borrowing compared to last year, but it was similar to last quarter 4. The net cash reserve declined to around $3.1 billion compared to last year, but flat against last quarter 4. 
Inventory days were 27 days, up 8 days again last year, due to our expansion into consumer business and emerging markets, ramp up for our new in-house manufacturing and integration of our recent acquisitions. They were up 1 day quarter-on-quarter due to increase in mobile internet device business and ramp up for our in-house manufacturing. Receivable days were 36, up 2 days compared to last year, also driven by our expansion in consumer business, as well as integration of our recent acquisitions. It was down quarter-on-quarter due to improvement in collection, as well as quarter 4 is typically our low season. 
Payable days were 64 days, down 2 days compared to last year, and 9 days compared to last quarter 4. The year-on-year change was in line with our normal trend, and the quarter-on-quarter change was due to seasonality. We remain at a very strong cash position for working capital needs to drive future growth. 
Next chart, please. We continue to do well in all geographies in quarter 1 for both our PC and mobile internet device business and our PC Plus strategy, resulting in margin improvement year-on-year in most regions. Our balanced geographic exposure, especially markets outside China, including Americas and EMEA continued to help contribute to our top line growth. We continued to record share gain across product and customer segments. 
We have combined Latin America with North America to form the new American region beginning from quarter 1 to further facilitate our operating efficiency, and we have reported our performance this time under the new 4 geographic classifications. We have enclosed in the appendix the historic performance for your reference. 
China. The revenue from China was up 6% year-on-year, driven by strong growth in our mobile internet device, which grew 76% year-on-year. Our smartphone business in China continued to be profitable in quarter 1 for the third consecutive quarter. Profitability of the overall mobile internet device business has also improved. Revenue from PC business was down 7% year-on-year. However, owing to the decline in the PC market, but we continue to strengthen our leadership and further improve PC operating margin. It was up year-on-year and quarter-to-quarter to 6.8%, as we focus on upholding margin in a declining market. As a result, our overall margin in China was up 0.6 points year-on-year and 0.5 points quarter-to-quarter to 5.2%. We remain confident that our PC Plus strategy is fully operational in China, and can continue to drive growth in sales and profit. 
Asia Pacific. Revenue was down 9% year-on-year to about $1.3 billion in Asia Pacific, which is a result of our decision to focus on profitability. We have given up some nonprofitable government-related transactions in the region, which resulted in the decline of our market share. Nevertheless, we continued to perform well in Japan and solidify our leadership position with share gains. We also recorded record high market share in ASEAN. Our operating margin was up 0.1 points to 0.9% year-on-year. 
EMEA, we had a very encouraging quarter in EMEA with record high market share. Revenue grew 18% year-on-year to about $1.9 billion. Strong growth in emerging markets and consumer business contributed to the strong growth in the region. We're #1 for the first time in Eastern Europe and we achieved #1 position in 10 countries, including Germany from 2 countries last year. Our operating margin was up 0.4 points to 1.5% year-on-year. 
Americas, we continue to achieve a strong growth premium against the market decline in the region, with record high market share at 9.7%. We continued to record strong growth in North America, up 17% for the first time to reach double-digit market share, driven by strong growth in the U.S. commercial business. We also performed well in Brazil. We showed a record high market at 9.5%. Operating margin, however, was down year-on-year, as we are still investing in Brazil, and consumer business in the region and integrating CCE operations in the short term. 
Next chart, please. We have a more balanced product portfolio helped by our expansion in consumer PC and mobile internet device business. Notebook units shipments were down around 2% with a 10% premium to the market, but sales were up 5% year-to-year, respectively, as the average selling price was up. Unit shipments and sales in our desktop business were flat, with a 10-point premium, but sales were down 3% year-on-year. 
Our mobile internet business continued to show strong performance, up 105% year-on-year in sales, led by smartphone and tablet business, which fueled the growth of the group. The mix of mobile internet device further increased to 14% from 7%. While becoming #1 in the PCs for the first time ever, we actually sold more smartphones and tablets than PC during this quarter, against for the first time ever. 
Before I end my presentation, I want to give you some color on the market outlook. Our PC Plus strategy has been working well to drive the group's growth in sales and profit with margin expansion in the past several quarters. Strong growth momentum in our mobile internet device business, especially our smartphone business in China, has helped fuel the group's solid growth with improving profitability. 
We expect this trend to continue. We'll continue to roll out our smartphone business in emerging markets, and our tablet business in mature markets. Our core PC business is performing well despite uncertainties in the global economy, impacting the PC market growth in the short term. There are still enormous opportunities for growth in the traditional PCs. We remain confident that we can continue to outperform the global PC market and to improve our operating margin. 
Lenovo will succeed in the PC Plus area, because we are best positioned to capture the opportunity where the market is going from a premium to mainstream and entry-level and from mature market to emerging markets. This is our strength, where we have proven with our success in PC, and we will replicate this success in the PC Plus era as well. 
We will stay focused on our efficiency improvement initiatives and growth opportunities. We will continue to invest in core competence building, and product innovation and redeploy resources to invest in the high-growth area to drive the sustainable future growth. We have a healthy balance sheet, which provide us the flexibility for our M&A strategy to capture opportunities in high-growth area that can help to accelerate our growth. 
Thank you very much. Now, we can take your questions.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Aug 14, 2013
componenttext:
So firstly, so our smartphone business now is profitable. So particularly, in China. So our business profit and also, we have a very different margin. So actually, our smartphone business margin in China is higher than our PC business. So but in short term, we think it is still in the investment period. We still needed to invest on the branding, we still needed to invest on the channel network building. So we don't expect to -- our smartphone business will contribute significantly to our overall profit, particularly outside China. So we will focus our emerging market to develop. So we still needed to invest in that area. So that's about the margin and the profit. So regarding of the competition, so we have never been scared with the competition, actually. So we think the market -- the recent market trends favor Lenovo and [indiscernible]. So we have seen this trend. So the market is shifting from the premium part to the mainstream. It's shifting from the mature markets to emerging markets. Actually last quarter, our
emerging markets accounts for more than 6% -- 64% of the total smartphone market. And also, even in mature markets, we see a refresh -- I mean, cycle is becoming faster and faster from the carriers. Carriers allow their customers to replace their phones in 1 year or even just 6 months, so like AT&T and T-Mobile. So I -- so we think this trend definitely is more appropriate -- the Lenovo business model. So as you know, we have very rich product portfolio across the whole price band. So we have very fast product -- revenue cycle. We emphasize our time-to-volume -- our time-to-market and the time-to-volume. So that's our long-term stronghold since our PC refresh [ph]. And also, we have a very efficient underlying business model with disciplined operation. So our in-house manufacturing can quickly turn our innovation into high-quality cost -- cost-effective products. So meanwhile, so although we are trying to improve our profitability, we always set a reasonable margin target. So this means that we are able to provide the customers, especially mainstream customers, truly affordable products, so compared to our current leaders in the smartphone and the tablet area. So that's 1 reason we are confident on the competition, definitely. The second reason is we are also are a very innovative company. So we are innovating not just in the sufficient PC area, we're innovating in the smartphone and tablet area as well. So in the second half of the year, so you will see a more exciting products from both PC and the PC Plus market. So we will launch our second generation of multimode products, including Yoga second generation, including the first generation of the multimode tablet, multimode tablet. So just to give you content. So -- and also, in the smartphone. So we will launch multiple mode -- models of a thinner and a lighter smartphones with features focusing on security, focusing on the collaboration across devices, focusing on the kind of service application. So I'm very confident on our competition with our key competitors in the market.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2013
componenttext:
Good Afternoon. Welcome to Lenovo's Q2 Earnings webcast. This is Gary Ng, VP in Investor Relations at Lenovo. Before we start, let me introduce our Management Team with us today. 
We'll have our Chairman and CEO, Mr. Yuanqing Yang, and our CFO, Mr. Wong Wai Ming.  We will first start with our management presentation. After that, we will take your questions. 
Now, let me turn it over to Yuanqing.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2013
componenttext:
Hello, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. 
I'm pleased to report that Lenovo once again delivered record results. Our formula for success starts with our clear strategy driving our strong execution. Our Protect and Attack strategy now focuses on protecting our core PC business, while aggressively attacking growth in PC Plus, which includes tablets, smartphones, and the servers. This clear strategy guided us to yet another record performance. Not only was our nearly $10 billion revenue was an all-time high, but more importantly, we achieved a record profit of $220 million, up 36% year on year. We promised to keep improving profitably and we delivered that. 
For PCs, Lenovo grew market share by more than 2 points year-on-year, and we remained the world's #1 PC company. Our market share reached the record of 17.7%. Our PC growth and the strong profitability were driven by our balanced global business across all geos. 
Now, Lenovo is #1 in 5 of the top 7 markets: China, Japan, Brazil, Germany, and Russia. And we are #3 in India. At the same time, we have reached a double-digit market share in U.S. for the first time. Brazil is particularly a highlight. Through the acquisition and the integration of CCE, we quickly built our foundation. It took us from #7 to #1 in just 3 quarters with the improved profitability. This exceeded our expectations. 
While we continued our success in PCs, our PC Plus business also had a very strong quarter. In smartphones, we continued to see strong growth last quarter. Our worldwide volume grew by 78% year on year to reach 12.2 million units and continued to close the gap to #3 player worldwide. 
In China, we strengthened our #2 position. At the same time, our expansion in our worldwide markets gained a real momentum. 
In just 4 quarters, we have reached double-digit shares in Indonesia, which has the fourth largest population in the world. And we are also seeing strong progress in key markets such as Brazil, India, Russia and Vietnam. 
Over the next couple of quarters, in our second wave, we are expanding to at least 20 more countries. We saw even faster growth in tablets, with sales volume up more than 400% year-on-year. This hyper growth came from balanced sales worldwide. At the same time, our tablet business continues to be profitable. I will talk a bit more about tablets in just a moment. 
Our combined sales of smartphones and tablets surpassed the PCs for the second straight quarter, and they now account for 15% of our overall business and continue to improve profitability. In both PCs and PC Plus, we delivered very strong performances. This definitely proves that our PC Plus strategy is working very well and are driving strong execution. 
We are confident that we can sustain this momentum quarter after quarter because in addition to our clear strategy, our investments in innovation and the business model will continue to pay off. 
Lenovo continues to refine PCs with innovative products like we did with the multimode portfolio: Yoga, Horizon, Helix, which were offering more growth and opportunities. At the same time, we will accelerate our growth in PC Plus products. 
In smartphones, we launched our flagship Vibe smartphones. Not only do they have more competitive features and a stylish design, but they will become a platform for Lenovo to expand our premium smartphone business globally. And just last week, Lenovo launched the highly anticipated multimode, uniquely designed Yoga tablet. It can really solve some pain points of current tablet customers. We do hope it will be one of the best-selling tablets for the holiday season. 
The Yoga tablet launch was also our latest brand building effort, which will be our next focus area. Ashton Kutcher is a superstar actor and he will definitely help us showcase our technology and innovation. 
And in addition to hardware devices, we will continue to invest in our ecosystem. So far there are over 400k apps in Lenovo store and over 20 million downloads daily, and these numbers are still growing.  
Actually, I hope you can try some of our most popular apps, such as [indiscernible] and the Lenovo [indiscernible]. Meanwhile, we will continue improving our business model, which has led to lower cost and a higher efficiency. Our new factory in Itu, Brazil was critical to our rapid rise to #1 in the Brazilian PC market. And just next month, our mobile product factory in Wuhan, China will officially start production, further strengthening our in-house manufacturing capability. Our business model is our competitive advantage and we will keep investing in it. 
Looking to the next few quarters, we are confident, not only because of our clear strategy, but also because we see the PC market improving and the growth in tablet shifting to our favor. Benefiting from our corporate refresh and the China market improvement, the sharpest declines in PC sales are now over. And just like I mentioned earlier, we are helping the PC market to recover with more and more innovative products. Although according to most industry analysts, customers no longer see tablets as a replacement for PCs. The vast majority of tablet buyers say tablets only prevent them from buying a PC. 
Actually, tablet is shifting to mainstream and entry-price brands, and are replacing notebook to become the important part of PC, particularly in emerging markets. If you combine PC and the tablet, you still can see very decent growth over the past couple of quarters. So with the PC market improving and the growth in tablets shifting, the key industry trends are moving to Lenovo's favor. In fact, if you combine PC and tablet together, Lenovo is already #2 worldwide in this measure. We want to firstly become the #1 in this category, and then challenge the top in all smart connected devices. 
Looking ahead, we are confident that Lenovo will continue to deliver outstanding performance in both PC and PC Plus, and we have proven that we deliver on our commitments, time after time, for now 18 straight quarters. 
Thank you very much. Now, let me turn to our CFO, Wai Ming.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2013
componenttext:
Thank you, Yuanqing. I will take you through Lenovo's financial and operational performance in quarter 2. 
Next chart, please. We continue to grow in both sales and pretax income with margin expansion, even as the global PC market declined in quarter 2. Lenovo recorded growth in all its key businesses: PCs, smartphone and tablet. Strong growth in our smartphone and tablet business has added an important new source of sustainable growth for the group and this has now accounted for 15% of the group's turnover compared to 8% in quarter 2 last year. Group sales grew 13% year on year to around $9.8 billion. This is a record high level for Lenovo. Despite the market dropped 10% year-to-year, revenue derived from our PC business has recorded a 4% year-on-year gain to about $8 billion, driven by both shipments growth and increase in our ASP. 
Sales in our mobile Internet business were up 106% year-on-year to $1.5 billion. Gross profit was about $1.3 billion, up 11% year-on-year. Gross profit margin dipped slightly to 12.9% from 13.1% last year and 13.6% in quarter 1. The decline is largely due to the increased mix of our consumer and mobile Internet businesses. 
Operating expenses increased 5% year-on-year to $982 million to support our growth. The operating expense in quarter 2 has included expenses incurred in the CCE and EMC joint venture, in which we started the integration in quarter 4 last year. 
We have continued our efficiency improvement program started last quarter which involved in taking resources reduction in our PC business, and deploying some of those in our high-growth PC Plus businesses. This result in a $50 million severance expense incurred in quarter 2. The E/R ratio was down to 10%, from 10.8% last year and 11.3% last quarter, due to better scaling benefits and shrink in expense control. Operating profits was $283 million, up 38% year on year. Increase in other non-operating expense was largely due to additional financing and hedging costs. Pre-tax income was $265 million, up 30% year on year and this is a record high level for the group. 
          
PTI margin continued to improve year-on-year and quarter-on-quarter, and we are on track to deliver a 1% PTI margin improvement over 3-year period as disclosed in quarter 2 last year. 
The effective tax rate for Q2 was around 20%, which is in line with our average run rate around 20% to 25%. Profit attributable to equity holders is $220 million, up 36% year on year. Again, this is also a record high level for the group. 
Basic EPS improved to USD 0.0212 from USD 0.0158 last year. The Board of Directors in today's meeting declared an interim dividend of HKD 0.06 per share, representing an increase of around 33% compared to last year.  Next chart, please. 
Our balance sheet in Q2 remains healthy. Noncurrent assets were about $4.7 billion, similar to last quarter. Current assets were also similar to last quarter, with a decline in cash and bank deposits, offset by increase in receivables, which is in line with our business growth. 
Inventory was relatively stable under tight control, even as we continue to increase our in-house manufacturing in China and Brazil, consolidation of our recent acquisition like CCE, as well as finished goods, especially for mobile Internet device to prepare for sales season in quarter 3. 
Net current liabilities were around $144 million, at the end of September. The noncurrent liabilities were at around $1.8 billion. 
Let's go for the cash and working capital in the next chart. We continue to leverage our strong cash position to support our strategic business expansion into high-growth areas, such as consumer business and mobile Internet device business, as well as enhancing our capability through increasing in-house manufacturing mix. This strategy continued to be in progress in quarter 2, as reflected in an increase in inventory to support the growth of both MIDH and Consumer business, as well as ramping up our new plants in China and Brazil. Adoption of this strategy also reflected on our cash conversion cycle trend. As a result, the cash conversion cycle has come down to negative 3 days in Q2 against negative 9 days last year. 
We recorded an operating cash outflow of 109 -- $189 million versus approximately an inflow of $140 million in Q1 this year and $143 million in Q2 last year. This yearly change is primarily due to a reduction of our cash conversion cycle of negative 3 days in Q2 versus negative 9 days last year as explained before.  The change when compared to Q1 is mainly due to the timing difference in relation to payment to certain suppliers. 
I want to emphasize here that the reduction of our cash position is a result of our strategic decision to leverage our balance sheet to invest in high-growth areas that resulted in our strong shipment growth in Q2. We expect this investment will help to continue our growth which, eventually, will be cash-generating in the near future. We expect the cash position to increase in Q3 and remain at a very strong cash position for working capital needs to drive future growth. Next chart, please. 
Despite the significant decline in the China market for the last few quarters, the group continues to maintain its overall growth in revenue, contributed by other geos that have been successfully expanding their business and recorded share gains. This resulted, the group now has a more balanced business derived from all our 4 geos. We continued to do well in all geographies in Q2 for both our PC and mobile Internet device business and our PC Plus strategy. Our balanced geographic exposure, especially markets outside China, including Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific, continue to help contribute to our top line growth. We continue to record share gains across geographies, products and consumer segments. Result of our initial expansion of our smartphone and tablet business in market outside China was encouraging. 
Total revenue from China was up 1% year on year driven by strong growth in mobile internet devices which grew 45% year on year. Our overall margin in China was up 1.3 points year-on-year, and 0.1 point quarter-to-quarter to 5.3%. This reflected the successful execution of our Protect and Attack strategy to protect China PC profit through tighter control on pricing and expense control, which resulted in improved PC operating margin, while continuously attacking into mobile Internet markets, which resulted in overall increase in revenue. 
Our smartphone business in China continued to be profitable for the fourth consecutive quarter in Q2. As a result, we remain confident that our PC Plus strategy is fully operational in China and can continue to drive growth in sales and profit in China. 
Asia Pacific. Revenue was up slightly 1% year on year to about $1.5 billion in Asia Pacific while operating profit increased over 30% year-to-year to $25 million, which is a result of our solid PC Plus execution. 
We continued to do well in Japan and maintained our leadership position, but depreciation of Japanese Yen had negatively impacted sales in the region. Our drive in smartphone in this region has been encouraging, and we have reached 10% market share in smartphone in Indonesia, according to preliminary industry estimate, a strong growth also in tablet shipment. 
Our operating margin was up 0.05 points to 1.7% year-on-year, under the strong progress in the PC Plus area. 
EMEA, we continued to have a very strong encouraging quarter in EMEA, with record high market share. Revenue grew 26% year-on-year to about $2.3 billion. Strong growth in emerging markets and Consumer business contributed to the strong growth in the region. We achieved #1 position in 12 countries, including Germany and Russia, from just 3 countries last year. Our mobile Internet business, especially tablet business in Europe has also recorded encouraging feedback. But we are in the early phase of development and need further investment in the business, and as a result, our operating margin was down 0.01 point to 1.5% year-on-year. 
Americas. We continue to achieve strong growth in the region, with record high double-digit share. Unit shipments grew 39% against the market decline by above 4%. This represent a premium growth of over 40% in Americas and we reached double digit market share in the U.S. for the first time, driven by the strong growth in the U.S. commercial and consumer business. 
We also performed well in Brazil. Our integration of CCE has been on track, helping us achieve a record high market share in Brazil with the improving profitability. However, due to a change in product mix, especially from selling more entry-level mobile Internet product in the rest of Latin America, coupled with the competition of PC business in the region, has resulted in lower operating margin year-on-year.  Next chart, please. 
We also have a more balanced product portfolio helped by expansion in Consumer PC and mobile Internet business. We had a record high market share in notebooks at around 19%. Notebook unit shipments and sales were up about 3% and 8% year-on-year respectively. Unit shipments in our Desktop business went up 1%, and sales down 3% year-on-year. Our market share in the worldwide desktop market increased to around 17%. Our MIDH business shows strong growth performance, up 1.06x year-on-year in sales led by the smartphone and tablet business, which fueled the strong growth of the group. We will continue to invest in innovation and broaden our product portfolio to enhance our competitiveness and service to our customers. 
Before I end my presentation, I would want to give you some color of the market outlook. Our PC Plus strategy has been working well to drive good growth in sales and profit with margin expansion in the past several quarters. Strong growth momentum in our mobile Internet device business has been the driver of the group's solid growth. Despite the PC market has been volatile over the past several quarters, the combined PC and tablet markets has continued to see growth, and we are confident that this trend will continue. We expect our core PC business will benefit from the improving worldwide PC market in the second half of the year from corporate refreshment and the gradual recovery in China PC market. There are still enormous opportunity for growth in the traditional PC areas. 
Given that our smartphone business has reached certain critical scale in China, we will focus in improving the margin, while we are expanding our smartphone business aggressively to markets outside China. We'll continue to invest in growth areas in consumer PC and smartphone and tablets to maintain a healthy top line growth. We'll stay focused on our efficiency improvement initiatives and growth opportunities. We'll continue to invest in core competence building and product innovation. We have taken resource action in our PC business and deployed resources to invest in the high-growth areas to drive sustainable future growth. We have a healthy balance sheet and strong cash position will provide the flexibility of our, for our M&A strategy to capture opportunities in high-growth areas that can help to accelerate our growth and improvement in profitability. 
Thank you very much. Now we can take your questions.
